 REPUBLIC OF COTE D'IVOIRE INTEGRATED HEALTH SERVICES DEVELOPMENT PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Republic of C6te d'Ivoire (RCI) Implementing Agency: Ministry of Public Health (MSP) Beneficiaries: Users of health services, particularly among the relatively less well off and presently under-served populations Poverty Category: The Project is part of the program of targeted interventions. Without being exclusively targeted towards the poor, the Project represents an operational, health systems-oriented approach to a poverty-conscious health services strategy. Credit Amount: SDR 27.7 million (US$40 million equivalent) Terms: Standard, with 40 years maturity Project Objectives. The objectives of the proposed Integrated Health Services Development Project, within the framework of the Government's National Health Development Plan, are to (a) expand access to health services and improve their utilization; (b) make health services available on a sustainable basis; and (c) improve the ability of the MSP to analyze health problems, and to formulate, monitor and evaluate policies, strategies and programs. The Project would seek to establish the foundation for universal availability of cost-effective, technically and culturally appropriate health services that are affordable and sustainable to the people and country as a whole, by expanding service delivery for a minimum package of health care and reproductive health services, and by expanding MSP capacity at the headquarters level. Project Description. The Project consists of a three-year set of priority Government programs in four main areas: (a) the minimum package of health services (PMA); (b) reproductive health; (c) health planning and management; and (d) information and health. Service delivery (components (a) and (b)) includes: (i) investment and start-up costs for PMA introduction in about fourteen districts, including nutrition, pharmaceuticals, training, reproductive health, and IEC services; and (ii) an
 ii accelerated program of reproductive health services, including family planning and sexually transmitted diseases (such as HIV/AIDS), through specialized public sector and NGO clinics and the addition of family planning services to non-specialized public sector health clinics. Institutional strengthening activities (components (c) and (d)) cover the following areas: (i) organization development of the MSP; (ii) information systems (MIS), including epidemiological surveillance (such as onchocerciasis) and continuous monitoring and feedback of user perspectives on services; (iii) training of prescribers in use of generic drugs and strengthening of quality control laboratory services; (iv) health care financing (including mutual insurance and complementary private insurance); (v) financial management; and (vi) review of training programs and strengthening of personnel management in further pursuit of actions started under the HRMP. Financing Plan. See para. 4.22. Project Benefits. The Project will contribute to long-term improvements in health outcomes, particularly reduced fertility, improved child health, and a relatively reduced burden from sexually transmitted and other diseases. The other benefits of the Project will be institutional: strengthened MSP capacity and strengthened service delivery, and expansion of the focus of health policy makers beyond traditional curative care to preventive services, reproductive health and - to some extent - nutrition. Work undertaken for WDR93, BHA, and other country-specific studies in Africa clearly demonstrate that the proposed approach - provision of a minimum package of health services by community-supported health centers, first referral hospitals, and health districts - is the least cost method to achieve substantial and sustainable health gains. Project Risks. The main non-quantifiable risks concern: (a) limited commitment to universally accessible, cost-effective PHN interventions that are feasible and sustainable, including particularly reproductive health, with the associated risk of political interference; (b) the resistance to change generated by substantial past investments in facilities and human resources oriented towards health services models, and a centralized public sector management culture, that are inconsistent with the social and economic realities and needs of the country; and (c) limited MSP and NGO capacity, both centrally and at the periphery, to execute government and donor-financed
 iii programs. These risks are being mitigated by institutionalizing regular beneficiary assessments, the recently completed institutional assessment of MSP and the follow-up organization development program, locating overall responsibility for the Project in the Minister's Cabinet, building institutional support for health services provided by community associations, local authorities, and NGOs into the Project, and limiting Project external financing to four years. Government ownership of the Project both outside and within the MSP needs, nonetheless, to be increased. A Project launch workshop will be held to that end, IEC activities are planned, allocations of staff time for supervision are planned commensurate to the task, and trust fund support for supervision work is being pre-programmed. The main risks that have been quantified concern an increase in the cost of the PMA, a decline in Government financial support to health, and the impact of reduced economic growth. A 50 percent increase in the cost of the PMA, either by under- estimation of present costs or by expansion of the range of services provided, would increase MSP expenditures on universal coverage of health services by about two-thirds; this shows the importance of attention to cost containment as Cote d'Ivoire pursues the goal of universal access to health care. Financing the PMA with GDP growth at 50 percent of the rate projected by the Bank, and with a 50 percent decline in the share of Government expenditures devoted to health would require an increase of one-third in the health share of household expenditures from its current level of 4.5 percent, to 6.0 percent. While conceivable, such a shift would require a major communications effort which a Government not giving priority to health would undoubtedly have difficulty making. Financing universal PMA coverage with a reduction of economic growth by 50 percent but keeping the current MSP share in Government expenditures is projected to be feasible, if necessary. The Government's MSP budget projections through 1999 are consistent with the growth path that would be needed to achieve universal coverage under the PMA program in ten years. Project ID: 1214

MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT AND COUNTRY ASSISTANCE STRATEGY 1.1 During the period 1980-93, the Government relied exclusively on internal adjustment measures to redress large fiscal and current account imbalances as well as the structural factors constraining dynamic private sector development and growth. However, this strategy failed to reverse the economic decline, which was particularly evident in the private sector. Against this background, the Government adopted a medium-term economic framework (MTF) in the early 1 990s which recognized the need to restore international competitiveness. But the actions carried out under the MTF were insufficient to reduce the overvaluation of the CFA franc and reverse the recession which actually deepened in 1993. 1.2 The 50 percent devaluation in January 1994 was accompanied by a comprehensive stabilization and structural adjustment program. It has shown encouraging results during the last two years. Inflation was brought under control within months following the parity change, yielding a change in the price index of 32.5 percent in 1994 and about 8 percent during 1995. The reduction of inflation was largely accomplished through a restrictive wage policy, by increasing nominal public sector wages less than inflation. As a result, the Government wage bill has fallen from about 10.7 percent of GDP in 1993 to 7.9 percent in 1994 and to 6.9 percent in 1995. A similar, although less restrictive, policy stance was adopted by the private sector. 1.3 Fiscal policy continues to be the cornerstone of the stabilization program. The Government met its revenue and expenditure targets in 1994 and 1995, thereby generating primary balance surpluses in the order of 1.6 and 3.2 percent of GDP respectively. While the reduction of many taxes (VAT, petroleum taxes, and import tariffs) in early 1994 helped dampen inflationary pressures, it reduced revenue as a share of GDP and required compensatory measures in the form of reintroducing export taxes on coffee and cocoa. However, the Government has since reduced the export tax on these commodities, and it is expected that their importance within overall government revenue will fall from about 27 percent in 1994-95 to less than 20 percent by the end of 1996. 1.4 With the successful stabilization effort, the Government has also deepened its structural adjustment program. Since the devaluation, the Government has implemented key components of its trade reforms, including a simplification and reduction of import tariffs as well as the elimination of a series of non-tariff barriers. Moreover, the Government has begun a far-reaching liberalization process in rice and maritime transport and shown its determination to confront vested interest groups in order to
 2 reduce transaction costs, thereby further increasing the competitiveness of the Ivorian economy. Other areas of progress include the acceleration of the privatization program, and the adoption of the new labor code and the new investment code. 1.5 Bank Group Assistance Strategv. The Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) was prepared following the devaluation and discussed by the Board in June 1994. The CAS supports the Government's objectives of increasing real GDP growth and strengthening external and internal competitiveness, as formulated in the 1994 PFP and its updates in 1995 and 19962. Major CAS priorities are to help the Government: (i) maintain macroeconomic stability and strengthen public sector finances through reforms in both revenue and expenditure; (ii) promote private sector development through continued liberalization of trade, financial and labor markets, and through investments in agriculture, industry, and transport; (iii) increase the effectiveness of the human resources development program through increased focus on primary health care, AIDS, basic education, and population policy; (iv) strengthen institutional capacity through existing IDA-supported technical assistance programs; and (v) intensify environmental work through projects and the National Environment Action Plan (NEAP) process. This strategy is being implemented as programmed. A CAS progress report has been circulated to the Board under separate cover. 1.6 The CAS identifies the resolution of the country's substantial public financing requirements, including heavy debt service obligations, as a critical factor in determining C6te d'Ivoire's economic prospects. The CAS envisages that the World Bank would help finance the Government budget through a series of fast-disbursing operations. The recently approved PSD Credit is an important element in this financing scenario. 1.7 In the area of social sector development, the Bank strategy notes that there are three major disparities in access to health care in Cote d'lvoire, by region, by income level and by gender. The historic concentration of services on curative action in the capital city and the neglect of such services as family planning and nutrition have accentuated these disparities. The less well-off population groups tend to use health services less than others. Since around 60 percent of medical consultations among the lowest two expenditures quintiles were at public sector health centers in 1995, and about 50 percent of consultations amnong the two highest quintiles were at public sector hospitals, a program, such as the minimum package (PMA), concentrated on strengthening services at health centers will benefit the poor relatively more than the rich. 1.8 MIGA. Cote d'Ivoire has been a member of MIGA only since 1988. MIGA has received nine preliminary applications for investments in the areas of oil and gas, manufacturing and financial services. The potential investors are from Canada, France, Switzerland and the United States, and planned investments total about US$170 million. 2 A third-year PFP was circulated to the Board on an information basis in early June 1996.

It is fairly optimistic about the country's economic prospects and continues to develop a solid pipeline of projects in the coming years provided the Government stays the course on the reform program. This positive stance is reflected in the exceptionally high level of approvals for C6te d'Ivoire during the past two years--US$96 million. HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENT 2.1 Cote d'Ivoire has traditionally given high priority to human resources in its public expenditures but has not had health achievements consistent with this priority. Corrective efforts were initiated in the early 1990s and will be accelerated under the proposed Project. More than 50 percent of budget outlays were consistently devoted to human resources in the 1981-91 period. By the late 1980s the deteriorating economic situation and inappropriate human resources policies led the country to have social indicators generally worse than those for countries with lower average per capita income levels and which spent significantly less on health and education. In addition, the structure of public expenditures on health was distorted in three ways: 3 First, too much was spent on curative care relative to preventive care. Curative care is generally both expensive and a private good, while preventive care generates many positive externalities, is much less expensive and is usually more cost-effective, even though private demand is generally low for preventive care. * Second, too much was spent on salaries relative to non-salary recurrent expenditure. The personnel share of recurrent expenditures grew from 67 percent in 1981 to over 75 percent in 1984. * Third, the share of medicines in recurrent public health expenditure declined continuously between 1981 and 1987. 2.5 In the 1980s, the structure of health personnel in Cote d'Ivoire was distorted by inappropriate staff ratios and competency profiles: The structure was top-heavy, with low and deteriorating nurse-to-doctor ratios. The capacity of the MSP to plan, program and monitor health activities was weak, reflecting the lack of trained personnel as well as poor technical and financial information systems. 2.6 Most curative health services were located in urban centers, and therefore were out of reach of the vast majority of the population. Also, it appeared that the population did not expect benefits from consulting the existing curative services because the perceived quality of the service provided was poor. As a result of these factors, consultation rates for curative health services were very low.
 5 2.7 Government health policies began to change in the early 1990s. The Human Resources Development Program (HRDP, 1991-1994) was intended by the Government to reverse the unfavorable trends in human resources development which threatened to compromise the country's efforts for human development. The Memorandum of the President on the operation articulated the principal goal as "increasing the quality of service delivery, while broadening the coverage at the primary levels in education and health and offering more demand-driven training opportunities". The envisioned goals required basic changes in the Ivorian civil service that failed to be fully institutionalized, not to mention internalized among the staff. These goals could hardly be achieved in one adjustment operation, since they represent the development task of a generation or more. 2.8 Despite its over-ambitious character, under the HRDP the Government made progress on a series of health issues, including pharmaceuticals, the first elements of a strategy based on primary care, decentralization and region-level management, and cost recovery. Cost recovery was an important achievement: Since October 1994, public sector primary care facilities have been allowed fully to recover the cost of medicines and the non-salary cost of curative medical interventions. In rural areas, health facilities retain 90 percent of these revenues, and in urban areas 65 percent, in blocked accounts at the local level to replenish drugs used in public sector facilities, and for locally determined operating and maintenance costs. B. HEALTH SECTOR FINANCING 2.9 In 1990, health expenditures in Cote d'Ivoire had about half of their sources in the public sector and half in the private sector3. More recent household survey data suggest that as much as 60 percent of health spending, or even more, may be private. However, much more is known about public spending than about private spending. Public spending on health was one of the major focal points of the HRDP. The Implementation Completion Report on the HRDP found continuing distortions in the allocations of government budgetary resources between primary and preventive health services functions and tertiary services functions.4 2.10 In 1994, the European Commission carried out a major review of public expenditures (EU PER) in the health sector.  6 (d) rising cost recovery receipts, with a need to ensure that they do not lead to reduction in public budget allocations for health; (e) a need to strengthen human resource planning, and to take action to respond with creative support for private assignments as an alternative to the emerging unemployment of medical graduates who cannot be absorbed by the public sector; and (f) a need to update norms for spending and health inputs established for the HRDP, and to use them for monitoring. Pursuit of the agenda of issues from the HRDP and the public expenditure review will continue under the proposed Project and the Government's sectoral program. The Government is determined to exploit the recommendations of the study, and the proposed Project provides funds for this. 2.11 The MSP Budget. Starting with the HRDP and then in connection with successive Policy Framework Papers and the preparation of the proposed Project, the Ivorian authorities and the Bank have had frequent discussions on the MSP budget. With the Bank's encouragement, in 1994 and 1996 supplemental budget allocations were made for health services, largely at the primary care level. During negotiations assurances were obtained that, by October 1 of each year, annual consultations will be held on MSP budget plans in respect of the forthcoming calendar year, and on execution in respect of the current calendar year; these reviews will encompass counterpart funds required for the proposed Project and the investment and recurrent funds required for approved district health development plans. The annual Policy Framework Paper will provide an opportunity to review the MSP budget in its macroeconomic context. 2.12 Private spending. Private spending on health services is much less well understood than public spending. According to household survey data, in 1993 and 1995 it amounted to $12 and $14 per capita. These figures compare with an estimate of $17 in 19906. (Annex 16 gives further information on household survey results.) Since private spending constitutes such a substantial share of total health expenditures, it is surprising that so little is known about it; this is one consequence of the intellectual heritage of the provident state and the orientation of public policy towards the supply of public sector health services. Under its emerging strategy, the Government expects to devote more attention than in the past to demand variables. 2.13 National health accounts. Data weaknesses and lack of analytical capacity and determination mean that the MSP has yet to address the interactions of Government, donor and household spending on health. However, the preparation of the proposed Project has led officials to become increasingly aware of the problem, and an initial set of national health accounts is to be prepared as part of the planning and management component of the proposed Project. The emphasis will be less on intellectual sophistication than on providing a practical tool to the MSP, and on strengthening its capacity to use it through training and staffing changes. 6Better Health in Africa, The World Bank, 1994.
 7 2.14 Health insurance. Publicly sponsored health insurance is provided for public sector employees, and the private sector has the beginnings of what could become an active private health insurance market. About 7 percent of the Ivorian population is covered by a private voluntary health insurance program. In 1994 and 1995, a governmental Commission on Social Security made proposals for the establishment of a publicly sponsored mutual insurance scheme oriented towards financing of universally available primary care. While the Commission envisaged a Government guarantee, the Government has wisely decided that whatever scheme is ultimately established will have to be entirely self-financing and without public guarantee. Under the proposed Project, the Government will prepare and introduce pilot mutual insurance at the district level, and consultant studies will examine the circumstances under which complementary private insurance, largely for tertiary care, could be expanded; a detailed work plan for these studies is now in preparation. Previous Bank Operations in the Sector and Lessons Learned 2.15 Health and Demographic Proiect: The Implementation Completion Report finds that the principal lessons learned from this project (Ln 2619-IVC) are: (a) Project scope and content should be coherent and support an agreed sector strategy and program that is based on a consensus and agreed among the different ministries concerned; (b) Agreement should be reached up-front on performance indicators, and be reviewed through Project launch workshops, annual programming exercises, and a mid- term assessment; (c) Project management arrangement should be agreed, including staffing commitments and roles of key technical units; (d) Bank missions should be more frequent, with skill mix tailored to the technical and management requirement of the project; the Bank may want to consider delegation of certain tasks to the Regional Mission; and (e) The Bank may want to consider a shorter time-frame for future Projects, with phased implementation based on an agreed work program; some dovetailing of projects will reduce staff losses and reduce the risks of financing gaps.

KEY ISSUES 2.20 Two central issues serve as organizing principles for reviewing health services and programs in C6te d'Ivoire: (a) program management and decentralization, to make a minimum package of quality health services universally available, for maximum improvement in health outcomes; and (b) new priorities in reproductive health, nutrition, and information, education and communication for behavior change. 1. Program Management and Decentralization: Ensuring Universal Access to Services 2.21 As indicated above, in the years since Independence C6te d'Ivoire has developed a substantial health infrastructure and trained large numbers of health care personnel. However, the models of health care that have driven these developments have been insufficiently adapted to the economic and social realities of the country. Services have been highly disease-oriented. Neither policy nor resource allocation has focused on overall health outcomes, nor on the difficult practical issue of providing care to all within a reasonable period of time. The country has developed an elitist cadre of health professionals, strongly oriented towards curative care provided by public sector hospitals located in the urban areas, particularly Abidjan. Relatively little attention has been given to public health. 2.22 As in other parts of the Ivorian public sector, the attitudes of MSP staff are highly centralized and services are under-managed. Centralization has been particularly problematic in the field of health because of the critical importance of contact and communication with the beneficiaries of health services. The disconnect between general statements of policy and the realities of resource allocation and day-to-day activities reflects the under-management of health services. Monitoring and information systems have been given little attention, particularly at the implementation stage. Work that was initiated on them under the Bank-financed Health and Demographic Project was delayed and unfortunately not completed before closure of the Loan. The MSP has become increasingly aware of these problems, and is determined to move forward with new information systems, for epidemiological surveillance, health system planning, and health system management. It has taken initial steps towards deconcentration of public sector health services, with the initiative to present budget data on a regional basis; but, meaningful decentralization to the country's health districts of financial and personnel authority remains a lofty and largely unrealized ideal. Furthermore, decentralization concerns not only the MSP but even more importantly the Ministry of Finance and the
 10 Ministry of the Civil Service, for the latter ministries hold most of the effective power over financial and personnel decisions. The information base in the MSP is weak on financial and personnel matters. The emergence of substantial receipts from medical consultations, starting in 1994, offers the possibility of reopening the issue of financial information and responsibility. The first step is for the MSP to master the information and tools that it now has available. The proposed Project will assist in this task. 2. New Priorities: Reproductive Health, Nutrition, IEC, and Partnerships with Non-Governmental Partners 2.23 Thanks in part to the consciousness-raising impact of recent major international conferences, such as the 1992 International Conference on Nutrition (ICN), the 1994 Cairo Conference on Population and Development, and the 1995 Beijing Conference on Women, the Ivorian health authorities are becoming increasingly aware of the importance of reproductive health, nutrition, and information, education and communication programs for health-related behavior change. The evolving visions of the role of the state, emerging internationally as well as in C6te d'Ivoire under its structural adjustment program, have led Ivorian health policy makers also to give increasing attention to new partnerships for better health with the Government's non- governmental partners. 2.24 The significance of the country's 3.8 percent annual population growth rate is beginning to penetrate the thinking and actions of policymakers, due in part to analyses of the census data collected under the Bank-financed Health and Demographic Project. Family planning programs have thus far only been financed by USAID and the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF), though new assistance from Germany is expected shortly as USAID phases out its assistance in the country. Cote d'Ivoire has the highest reported levels of HIV seropositivity in West Africa. As in many other countries, however, the willingness to confront a disease that is transmitted by behavior widely viewed as socially unacceptable has been limited among opinion leaders. The Cairo Conference led the authorities to prepare a voluminous report, and has contributed to an atmosphere legitimizing discussion of reproductive health. The MSP has for some years had programs of cooperation with the local affiliate of IPPF and - more recently - with an internationally backed local private voluntary organization which provides anonymous AIDS testing. It is now working on the preparation of a broader program of cooperation which will include financial support to purely local NGOs and community associations to expand health services, particularly for hard-to- reach target populations. The most recently published surveys place protein-calorie malnutrition at 20 percent in urban areas and 28 percent in rural zones. A National Commission on Food and Nutrition is preparing a long-term strategy for food security, in pursuit of the understandings reached at the ICN, but operational activity does not yet exist and the MSP is notably weak in its human resources assigned to nutrition. IEC has existed, as a health activity, in Cote d'Ivoire, for many years, but has been given little priority in a highly medicalized health environment. Thus what is needed now is renewal

SECTOR STRATEGY REVIEW FOR THE CONSULTATIVE GROUP 3.1 Following the devaluation of the CFA franc and in preparation for the June 1995 meeting of the Consultative Group for Cote d'Ivoire, the Government undertook a major review of its health strategies. The Government health strategy statement prepared for the Consultative Group found that, despite improvements under the HRDP, the sector continues to suffer from the absence of planning, weaknesses in programming and budgeting, and the inability to manage its personnel. Budgeting was considered to be limited in its scope, and supervision of budget execution insufficient. Norms for services were found to be lacking, despite the importance given to this subject under the HRDP. Poor information management made budget monitoring deficient, and bureaucratic inertia made execution of budgets in the interior particularly difficult. Personnel are, the statement finds, poorly motivated and poorly distributed in the country. A disequilibrium was noted between curative and preventive services. The Govermnent strategy document found three major problems: (a) poor access to care; (b) inadequate adaptation of services to the expectations of beneficiaries; and (c) the limited credibility of modern medicine by comparison with traditional practices. 3.2 The Government's Consultative Group health strategy statement fixes the following principal sectoral objectives: reducing morbidity and mortality (including infant and child mortality); maternal mortality; eradication or control of infectious and parasitic diseases, both old (malaria, TB, etc.) and new (HIV); and reduction in nutritional weaknesses (particularly iodine and vitamin A). Additional objectives include managing population growth at the family and national level, and improving the internal and external efficiency of the health and social system. To achieve efficiency gains, the Government states that it proposes to organize health care on the basis of a minimum package of health services (PMA), to reform initial and in-service training programs, to facilitate establishment of recent graduates in private medical practice, and to finalize the information system initiated under the Health and Demographic Project. To consolidate progress under the HRDP, the Government proposes to pursue rehabilitation and maintenance of health infrastructure, increase the availability of and access to essential drugs by actions in the public and private sectors, institute a real deconcentration of services, strengthen the economic and financial management of the health system, promote effective community participation in the management of health services, strengthen service quality, reinforce coverage, and create a system of health insurance. 3.3 At the Consultative Group general support was expressed for the Government's strategy statement, and the Government was encouraged to move forward and make it increasingly operational. Since that time the Government has been giving increasing
 12 attention to donor coordination in the health sector. Meetings of donors chaired by the Minister of Public Health are held approximately every three months, and informal sub- sectoral consultations are held as needed. In June 1996, the MSP will hold a health sector round table meeting in Abidjan, as part of the agreed follow-up on the Consultative Group. The Government's health policy letter (Annex 2) follows closely the Government's planned presentation to the round table of its ten year National Health Development Plan. 3.4 The tendency of donor funding to follow donor rather than Government priorities, to concentrate on technical assistance, and not to be fully integrated into Government accounting has made managing donor relations a particularly difficult task in the health sector. The MSP has become increasingly sensitive to this problem over the past several years, and expects to take the initiative to address it in connection with the round table. A first step will be to establish a reasonable data base. The annual reviews of the sector program which the MSP expects to undertaken with its financiers will help to strengthen donor coordination. Thus, the round table should be seen as but one step in a larger and longer process of gradual integration of donor funding into an increasingly complete sector investment and development program. The proposed Project is a step in this direction. Donors have been engaged in the dialogue during its preparation, and the Government expects them gradually to join in financing a broad sectoral program with common national service norms. 3.5 The MSP public investment program for 1995-1997 set out in the Consultative Group document is sound in concept, but over-ambitious in level, at 90 billion CFA francs (US$180 million). Pursuing themes in its presentation to the Consultative Group, the policy letter underscores the following strategies: (a) promotion of primary care based on a minimum package of health services (PMA); (b) promotion of a multi- sectoral approach and partnerships with actors outside the MSP; (c) improvement in

PROJECT OBJECTIVES 4.1 The objectives of the proposed Integrated Health Services Development Project, within the framework of the Government's National Health Development Plan, are to (a) expand access to health services and improve their utilization; (b) make health services available on a sustainable basis; and (c) improve the ability of the MSP to analyze health problems, and to formulate, monitor and evaluate policies, strategies and programs. The Project seeks to establish the foundation for universal availability of cost-effective, technically and culturally appropriate health services that are affordable and sustainable to the people and country as a whole, by expanding service delivery for a minimum package of health care and reproductive health services, and by expanding MSP capacity at the headquarters level. The Project represents the first, three-year phase of a process, already initiated by the MSP with the establishment of an initial set of studies and pilot projects and PPF support, which is expected to lead to a fully integrated sector development and expenditure program. The Project is fundamentally an institutional development program, with emphasis on making change in service delivery oriented towards priority target populations. It is a key element of the Government's National Health Development Plan (PNDS). 4.2 The Project aims to strengthen MSP services at two levels: (a) at the service delivery level, particularly at the periphery, through a minimum package of health services (PMA, in its French acronym, for Paquet Minimum d'Activites) to be provided by health districts, complemented by strengthened or new national programs in the new priorities discussed above - reproductive health, information, education and communication for behavior change, and partnerships with non-governmental partners. The definition, costing, financing, and introduction of the PMA in an initial series of health districts is the central operational objective of the project. Financing of PMA introduction at the local level will be driven by requests from health districts formulated as district health development plans. Success with the PMA implies not only delivery of quality health care services but also the availability and financial accessibility of a limited number of essential drugs and acceptable levels of utilization by beneficiaries. Effective PMA introduction will be a long and demanding process, taking a number of years to reach the entire population. For this reason, providing family planning services solely in association with PMA introduction risks delaying the country's new priorities; reproductive health services will, for a period, be introduced not only in districts benefiting from PMA support to health development plans but also separately in other public sector health clinics where they are not yet available.
 15 (b) at the manazement level (headquarters, regions, and departments or districts) by supporting the long-term institution-building program of action research, studies, training and pilot projects described above. At the MSP headquarters level, the central objective of the Project is execution and effective follow-up on an institutional assessment of the organization, including strengthening of its informatics capacity. Execution of the assessment started in May 1995 with PPF support. Three years of experience with management and coordination of the MSP program of studies, training and pilot activities are expected to strengthen the Ministry's capacity for strategic management. A gradual change in perspective in the Ministry is expected, with increasing attention to demand variables and beneficiary perspectives. Private voluntary providers and community associations will be engaged to the maximum feasible extent, but the Project does not addresses the changes that will be required in the long term among the country's very conservative private-for-profit health care providers. Over the three year period of Project execution, the groundwork will be laid for a substantial increase in voluntary private insurance, to complement the planned mutual insurance program, and for the gradual reallocation of priority in public sector financial and human resources from the tertiary to the primary and secondary levels. B. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 1. The Minimum Package (PMA) ($16.4m) 4.3 The idea of a minimum package of health services (PMA), strongly promoted in VW'DR93 and BHA, is welcome in Cote d'Ivoire. The most cost-effective health services are already included in the Government's health programs, but they do not receive the financial support, human resources and other priorities required to ensure quality services and full utilization of existing infrastructure. The technical work on the definition of a core set of services which will receive priority in the allocation of public financial and human resources has been completed. An MSP working group prepared initial proposals for the contents of the PMA in March and April 1995, with suggestions that it be delivered by health centers and district hospitals. As refined in January, 1996, the list of services (Annex 6) includes: maternal care, delivery, post-natal care; well-baby care, including immunizations; family planning; limited curative care (malaria, STDs, acute respiratory infections, diarrhea); limited chronic care (TB, leprosy, dracunculiasis, yaws); and promotional services (nutrition, water supply and sanitation). 4.4 The PMA will be made operational through preparation and implementation of a series of district health development plans. These plans will specify infrastructure rehabilitation, re-equipment, and - where necessary - new construction for district headquarters, first referral hospitals (h6pitaux generaux), and health centers; refresher and on-the-job training; disease surveillance and reporting; IEC; recapitalization of drug stocks where necessary; tools for planning and monitoring; links to other services (such as water supply and sanitation) which have a bearing on health outcomes, and links to higher levels of the health care system. Districts will have to meet certain eligibility
 16 requirements for access to public financial resources to implement their plans; incentives for sound performance will be established. The general orientation of the work to be done at the MSP in support of the PMA will be to respond to community demand rather than simply to offer new supply. Technical staff in the MSP are to provide support to health districts in the preparation of their plans, and to advise decision makers at MSP headquarters on the quality of the plans. The Project will strengthen the DSC to enable it to support PMA work, especially in rural areas, through provision of equipment, training in health planning and management, and the provision of consultants' services. 4.5 Over the three year period of execution of the Project, the Government expects to introduce the PMA in about fourteen of the country's fifty planned health districts. However, this does not imply that the total population of each district will be reached in this period, as further time will be required to complete the construction (where necessary) and rehabilitation of health care facilities and the introduction of the training and supervision which form an essential part of the PMA. PMA monitoring and evaluation will be carried out by the health districts under the guidance of the DSC and with the support of a PMA unit in the Minister's Cabinet. This activity will assume increasing importance as the PMA is introduced in growing numbers of health districts, and financial support is provided to the districts by the MSP and donors. Work plans and informal understandings, in the form of agreed lettres de mission, setting out mutual expectations, will need to be adopted and monitored; adjustments may be required in PMA services according to the varying epidemiological conditions and socio-economic circumstances of different parts of the country. The PMA component of the proposed Project will not be limited to services provided by public sector health facilities, as it includes an experimental element of support to services provided by community associations, local authorities, and NGOs (see para 5.11); this pilot activity is responsive to the theme of partnerships with other actors for health improvement in the Government's letter of health policy. In the interest of establishing and implementing national standards for health services, the work on PMA policies supported under the proposed Project will apply throughout the country, rather than solely in the fourteen districts with plans to be financed by IDA; other interested donors will also be involved in the PMA work, under the general umbrella of the National Health Development Plan. 4.6 The following criteria will be used in reviewing health district development plans for financing: (a) criteria addressed to the district team: quality planning, following national norms and engaging the totality of the health services partners at the district level, and sustainability, particularly in respect of financing incremental recurrent costs; (b) criteria addressed to the central authorities: stability in the assignment of personnel, and training of the district team; (c) criteria addressed to the local authorities: participation in financing of the district plan, to be negotiated locally; (d) criteria addressed to the regional directorates: support by the regional directorate concerned. However, as detailed in Annex 18, the C6te d'lvoire PMA interventions were compared with minimum packages in other African countries where detailed studies have been made, including Guinea and Kenya. Broadly speaking, the most cost-effective interventions are included in the C6te d'Ivoire PMA. The comparisons suggest that Cote d'Ivoire will need to: (a) give increasing attention, in

The responsibility for determining and financing exemptions to the universal cost recovery rules lies at the commune level. 4.21 To review the fiscal impact of the Project, projections were made of the implications of providing universal coverage of the population under the PMA and of providing universal coverage under the present, hospital-oriented health care services. Universal coverage under the present, hospital-based pattern of health services is projected to require Government health expenditures of CFA francs 201 billion. In fifteen years projected resources available annually for Government financing of health services are CFA francs 176 billion under the Bank's standard economic growth scenario, on the assumption that historical budget shares are not changed. The Government's MSP budget projections through 1999 are consistent with the goal of achieving universal PMA coverage in ten years. D. BENEFICIARIES, TARGET GROUPS, AND PARTICIPATION 5.14 Health equity is a major issue in CMte d'Ivoire. In 1995, the richest quintile of the population benefited from 31 percent of public spending on health, whereas the poorest quintile had only 11 percent. The public health subsidy is poorly targeted: The poorest 40 percent of the population received only 29 percent of the public subsidy in 1995, while the richest quintile received 31 percent. The per capita health subsidy is 34 percent lower in rural areas than in urban areas. The pattern of hospital care and financing lies behind this targeting issue; it should also be noted that the per capita subsidy in rural hospitals is less than one-third that in urban hospitals. Cote d'Ivoire will join in a Bank- sponsored research project which should help it to target public budget funds more effectively as a function of poverty and income. Public officials are increasingly aware of and sensitive to health equity issues but it must be recognized that they are long-term, fundamental problems in the political economy of health and development in CMte d'Ivoire. 5.15 The proposed Project aims to create a foundation for universal access to health services, which would be a great achievement in the fight against poverty in Cote d'Ivoire. The ultimate beneficiaries of the Project will be concentrated among those who are relatively less well off. The PMA is designed to reach the entire Ivorian population, but its core interventions are of greatest interest to the poorer population. The Observatoire des Beneficiares will help to make public sector health services more responsive to the perceived needs of the people, and particularly of the poor. The PNDS is not, by definition, targeted towards the poor, and it must be recognized that the less well off population groups tend to use health services less than others. It is expected that, over time and beyond the period of Project execution, the PMA will lead to substantially higher levels of use of health services among the poorer population. Since around 60 percent of medical consultations among the lowest two expenditure quintiles were at public sector health centers in 1995, and about 50 percent of consultations among the two highest quintiles were at public sector hospitals, a program, such as the PMA, concentrated on strengthening services at health centers will benefit the poor relatively more than the rich. Thus, without being exclusively oriented towards the poor, the Project represents an operational, health systems-oriented approach to a poverty- conscious health services strategy.
 28 5.16 Findings from the 1995 household survey shed light on poverty and health services, and the importance of the changes to be promoted by the proposed Project. According to the survey results, people in the lowest expenditure quintiles were less likely to report an illness than those in better off households; among those who reported an illness in the two weeks previous to the survey, nearly 50 percent sought medical care; the proportion of women seeking care was lower than would be expected; non-poor households spent an average of CFA francs 28,500 on health care, poor households lying between the two National Institute of Statistics (INS) poverty lines spent only 19 percent of this amount, and households in the poorest decile spent only 7 percent. Taking the initiative for preventive care consultations was all but unknown. Over 90 percent of consultations for modem health services were reported to have taken place in public sector facilities. Pharmaceuticals (excluding traditional medicines) made up about 50 percent, and in some cases even more, of household expenditures on health in 1995; pharmaceuticals are - by far - the principal household concern when questions are asked about health services. The public subsidy on health care was 34 percent lower in rural than in urban areas, the amount going to the lowest quintile was 64 percent lower than the per capita mount obtained by the highest quintile; only 11 percent of public sector health spending benefited the poorest 20 percent of the population, and 30 percent of spending benefited the poorest 40 percent. 5.17 The Project preparation process engaged a wide range of stakeholders in a series of client consultations, and this dialogue will continue during Project execution and beyond. The client consultations (see Annex 15) addressed the future of health care in Cote d'Ivoire; health perceptions, attitudes and practices of a wide range of heads of households in two health districts; and motivation and behavior of health care providers in Cote d'Ivoire. The private sector was seen to be quite defensive, and limited in its geographical reach. Public and private sector providers both have a certain skepticism regarding the other. A gradual rapprochement between the two should be sought. Deterioration in confidence of the people in both public and private providers was noted. Initially, the MSP staff were reluctant to listen to others' views. Thanks to the client consultations, and the Observatoire des Beneficiaires to be established under the proposed Project, greater openness can be expected; the client consultations will be continued, as needed, under the Observatoire des Beneficiaires program. Furthermore, the demand-based approach to district health development plan financing and implementation will strengthen the need for providers to participate in a dialogue with beneficiaries. The management committees (COGES) for health facilities will be an important forum for the participation of beneficiaries in the management of public sector health services. Finally, the establishment of a framework for dialogue between the MSP and community groups, and the pilot services to be provided by them, will increase the participation of beneficiaries in MSP services at both the policy and operational levels, and complement the other actions taken to give increasing attention to demand variables.

PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS 6.1 Proiect Benefits. The immediately measurable benefits of the Project will be institutional: strengthened MSP capacity and strengthened service delivery, and expansion of the focus of health leaders beyond traditional curative care to preventive services, reproductive health, and - to a lesser extent - nutrition. While attribution to the Project is virtually impossible, the programs to be supported by IDA are expected to contribute to long-term improvements in health outcomes, particularly reduced fertility, improved child health, and a relatively reduced burden from sexually transmitted and other diseases. Work undertaken for World Development Report 1993 - Investing in
 35 Health, Better Health in Africa, and other country-specific studies in Africa clearly demonstrate that the proposed approach - provision of a minimum package of health services by community-supported and managed health centers, first referral hospitals, and health districts - is the least cost method to achieve universal coverage and substantial and sustainable health gains. See Annex 18. 6.2 Project Risks. The main non-quantifiable risks concern: (a) limited commitment to universally accessible, cost-effective PHN interventions that are feasible and sustainable, including particularly reproductive health, with the associated risk of political interference; (b) the resistance to change generated by substantial past investments in facilities and human resources oriented towards health services models, and a centralized public sector management culture, that are inconsistent with the social and economic realities and needs of the country; and (c) limited MSP and community group capacity, both centrally and at the periphery, to execute Government and donor- financed programs. These risks are being mitigated by institutionalizing regular beneficiary assessments, the recently completed institutional assessment of MSP and the follow-up organization development program, locating overall responsibility for the Project in the Minister's Cabinet, building institutional support for community groups into the Project, and limiting project external financing to three years. The option, of a 'simple' Project (limited, say, to a fully pre-defined set of health activities) might make the IDA-financed activity appear relatively easy to execute, as an isolated operation. But, it would increase the geographical division of health services among donors and would not be able to address the fundamental health sector policy and institutional issues that inhibit accelerated improvements in health outcomes and widening coverage with health services in Cote d'lvoire, nor would it be any easier when Project activities were integrated into regular Government programs at the operating stage. Government ownership of the Project both outside and within the MSP needs, nonetheless, to be increased. A Project launch workshop will be held to that end, IEC activities are planned, allocations of staff time for supervision are planned commensurate to the task, and trust fund support for supervision work is being pre-programmed. 6.3 The main risks that have been quantified concern an increase in the cost of the PMA, a decline in Government financial support to health, and the impact of reduced economic growth. A 50 percent increase in the cost of the PMA, either by mis- estimation of present costs or by expansion of the range of services provided, would increase MSP expenditures by about two-thirds; this shows the importance of attention to cost containment as Cote d'Ivoire pursues the goal of universal access to health care. Financing univeral coverage with PMA services, with GDP growth at 50 percent of the rate projected by the Bank, and with a 50 percent decline in the share of Government expenditures devoted to health, would require an increase of one third in the health share of household expenditures from its current level of 4.5 percent, to 6.0 percent. While conceivable, such as shift would require a major communications effort which a Government not giving priority to health would undoubtedly have difficulty making. Financing universal PMA coverage with a reduction of economic growth by 50 percent but keeping the current MSP share in Government expenditures would still be feasible,
 36 for it would not require an increase of the Ministry of Public Health budget above projected values. Thus the Bank's economic growth scenario underscores the great value of a sound macroeconomy for health improvement but suggests also that the PMA should be sustainable even with economic growth at about the same rate as population growth. This would not be the case if Cote d'Ivoire were to seek universal coverage under its present pattern of expensive hospital-based health services. 7. These tasks need to be completed before project execution can effectively begin, and consultant assistance to the MSP is planned in this area. The final, operational version of the monitoring and evaluation program, including particularly the component-specific indicators, should be included in the project execution manual to be completed as a condition of Credit effectiveness. doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Integrated Health Services Development Project, within the framework of the government's National Health Development Plan, are to: 1) expand access to health services and improve their utilization; 2) make health services available on a sustainable basis; and 3) improve the ability of the Ministry of Public Health (MSP) to analyze health problems, and to formulate, monitor and evaluate policies, strategies and programs. The project components are as follows: 1) the minimum package of health services (PMA); 2) reproductive health; 3) health planning and management; and 4) information and health. The first two components - service delivery - include the following: (a) investment and start-up costs for PMA introduction in about 14 districts, including nutrition, pharmaceuticals, training, reproductive health, and information, education and communication services; and (b) an accelerated program of reproductive health services, including family planning and sexually transmitted diseases. The last two components - institutional strengthening activities - cover the following areas: (a) organization development of the MSP; 2) information systems, including epidemiological surveillance and continuous monitoring and feedback of user perspectives on services; 3) training of prescribers in use of generic drugs and strengthening of quality control laboratory services; 4) health care financing; 5) financial management; and 6) review of training programs and strengthening of personnel management.
